page.title: 09Coppicing Around Staplehurst
page.content: At West End Cottage to the west of Staplehurst parish the Collins pursue their occupation of fence making (or coppicing). Mr.Collins has done this work for some 35 years.He is called a pale maker". There are also two other people in the area who do this work. Sweet chestnut is used because it is a hard wood that lasts. Straight poles are felled from trees with 10-12 years growth when they have a diameter of 4-5 inches at eye level. Mr.Collins fells about three acres a year. He splits the poles with a double sided axe and points them on a chopping block before taking them to be wired. The wood is used on racetracks and motorways. A well managed acre of coppice can produce a mile of fencing and a pale maker produces approximate- ly 100ft. of paling a day.Trees are ready for coppicing at 14-18 years old
